position.marginalia_text: Quia sicut ista sunt nigra & obscura respectu diei, sic corpus putrefactum, respectu corporis mundi, quod ex putrefactione oritur, seu per nostru[m] Artificiu[m] extrahitur. Sed cuius Coloris debet esse istud corpus mundum? Certe albi coloris: Vnde Hermes: &c

marginalia.translation: Because just as these things are black and dark with respect to the day, so is the body putrefied, and with respect to the body of the world, which springs from putrefaction, and is extracted through our artifice. But what colour should the body of the world be? Certainly it is white, according to Hermes etc.

position.marginalia_text: Supra montem extensum in Cacumen, voce magna &c Ego sum Albus nigri, et Citrinus Albi, et Rubeus citrini: veridicus sum recte, et non mentior. Notetis ergo, Albus nigri: na[m] ip[su]m Album ex nigro extrahim[us]. Item Alphidius: Argentum viuum quod ab eo, s[cilicet] corpore nigro extrahitur, est humidu[m] Albu[m] &c

marginalia.translation: With strong voice it says over the mountain: I am the white of the black, and the yellow of the white and the red of the yellow. I am truthful, and I do not lie. Therefore, note the expression white of black, for the white itself is extracted from the black. Likewise Alhpidius says: quicksilver, which is extracted from a black body, is wet white etc.

position.marginalia_text: Viso ergo quod primus motus Natura[e], est putrefacere, videndum est &c

marginalia.translation: Therefore it is shown that the prime mover of nature is putrefaction, it need to see etc.
